nodes.text: Counties have causal effects on children's adult incomes; estimating each county's effect identifies which places produce better intergenerational mobility and why

Method: identify county causal effects using a movers-based fixed effects regression that regresses children's age-26 income ranks on county fixed effects interacted with fraction of childhood spent in each county, including origin-by-destination fixed effects and controls

Key identification assumption: conditional on origin-by-destination fixed effects, variation in childhood exposure time to each county is orthogonal to other determinants of child outcomes (no age-dependent selection)

Validation evidence: (i) controlling for parents' income and marital status around the move does not change estimates; (ii) placebo tests using movers after exposure window (moves after age 23) and teenage labor-force participation produce estimates uncorrelated with baseline estimates

Estimation implementation: estimate commuting-zone (CZ) effects with a two-step procedure from cross-CZ movers, then estimate county-within-CZ effects from within-CZ county movers; normalize effects to mean zero and allow effects to vary with parental income percentile

Result — magnitude: for children from low-income families (parents at 25th percentile), one year of exposure to a one-standard-deviation better county raises age-26 household income by about 0.5% (≈0.17 percentile points); cumulative 20-year exposure from birth to a one-SD better county implies ≈10% higher income

Result — variation: substantial heterogeneity exists across counties and within CZs; county-level signal standard deviation of annual effects for p=25 is ~0.17 percentile (signal), implying nontrivial place-by-place differences

Forecasting method: construct MSE-minimizing forecasts of county causal effects by optimally shrinking noisy mover-based fixed effects toward predictions from permanent residents' outcomes (weighted by precision), producing more precise unbiased forecasts for policy use

Forecast examples and magnitudes: among large counties, DuPage County, IL is forecasted to yield the highest gains for low-income children (≈0.80% per year; ≈16% from birth), while Cook County (Chicago) is near the bottom (≈−13% from birth), so moving from Cook to DuPage at birth implies large average gains

Heterogeneity: (a) counties with less concentrated poverty, lower inequality, better school outcomes, more two-parent families, and lower crime produce better outcomes for low-income children; (b) boys' outcomes vary more across areas than girls' and have a thicker negative tail in high-poverty segregated areas

Causal versus selection decomposition: for many area-level predictors (segregation, inequality, school quality, social capital) most of the observed correlation with upward mobility is causal rather than selection-driven, while for aggregated individual demographics (fraction single mothers, racial composition, immigrant share) a substantial share of observational correlations reflect selection

Housing market and policy implication: within CZs, rents are only weakly correlated with causal effects (rents explain <5% of variance in county causal effects for p=25), creating many 'opportunity bargains' (places that yield good child outcomes without high rents), suggesting rent-based voucher rules may not target neighborhood quality efficiently

Limitation: identification relies on the strong orthogonality assumption for each county and on constant additive exposure effects across childhood and across children conditional on parent income; estimates are county-level averages and may mask within-county heterogeneity

Policy and research implications: forecasts can guide families and policymakers to higher-opportunity counties; further research should (i) estimate effects at finer geographies and by subgroup (race), and (ii) isolate mechanisms (e.g., causal role of segregation, schools) via exogenous policy variation
